ec_class.name: Oxidoreductases
ec_class.description: To this class belong all enzymes catalyzing oxido-reductions. The substrate oxidized is regarded as hydrogen or electron donor. The classification is based on 'donor:acceptor oxidoreductase'. The common name is 'dehydrogenase', wherever this is possible; as an alternative, 'acceptor reductase' can be used. 'Oxidase' is used only where O(2) is an acceptor. Classification is difficult in some cases, because of the lack of specificity toward the acceptor.

ec_subclass.name: Acting on a Sulfur Group of Donors
ec_subclass.description: A small subclass acting either on inorganic substrates or organic thiols. Sub-subclasses again depend on the acceptor; EC 1.8.1 with NAD(+) or NADP(+); EC 1.8.2 with a cytochrome; EC 1.8.3 with oxygen; EC 1.8.4 with a disulfide; EC 1.8.5 with a quinone; EC 1.8.7 with an iron-sulfur protein; and EC 1.8.99 with other acceptors. Note that some such enzymes with NAD(+) as acceptor are listed under EC 1.6.4 .1-4

synonyms.synonym: Methyl sulfoxide reductase I and II

cml:reaction.title: RHEA:19995
cml:reaction.cml:name: L-methionine (S)-S-oxide + thioredoxin => L-methionine + H(2)O + thioredoxin disulfide

reactions.reaction: L-methionine + thioredoxin disulfide + H(2)O = L-methionine (S)-S-oxide + thioredoxin

comments.comment: Requires NADPH (2). The reaction occurs in the opposite direction to that given above. Dithiothreitol can replace reduced thioredoxin. L-methionine (R)-S-oxide is not a substrate (see EC 1.8.4.14, L-methionine (R)-S-oxide reductase).
The reaction occurs in the opposite direction to that given above. Dithiothreitol can replace reduced thioredoxin. L-methionine (R)-S-oxide is not a substrate (see EC 1.8.4.14). Formerly EC 1.8.4.5.

links.link: L-methionine (S)-S-oxide + thioredoxin => L-methionine + H(2)O + thioredoxin disulfide

enzyme.history: EC 1.8.4.13, created 1984 as EC 1.8.4.5, part-transferred 2006 to EC 1.8.4.13
